newsitem.title: CANADA: CBRS confirms Ontario ratings with stable outlook.
newsitem.headline: CBRS confirms Ontario ratings with stable outlook.

text.p: Canadian Bond Rating Service on Friday said if confirmed Ontario's long- and short-term debt ratings at AA and A-1+ respectively with a continued stable outlook for both.
In confirming the ratings, the Montreal-based bond rating agency noted the province managed to managed to better its deficit target for a second year because of higher-than-projected revenues.

CBRS also noted that the province's 1997 budget included a C$650 million contingency fund, assumptions of economic growth below those of the private sector and interest rate assumptions higher than those of the private sector.
The agency said Ontario's economy, the largest of any province in Canada, is performing quite well with auto and housing sectors doing very well.

Ontario's fiscal situation continues to improve at a steady pace, but at C$6.6 billion and C$108 billion the province's deficit and overall debt remain high, CBRS said. As a result, the agency said it will continue to monitor Ontario's ratings as it progresses towards a balanced budget.

CBRS said it will take at least another three fiscal years to achieve a balanced budget in Ontario and the province's high level of debt will remain a challenge. The agency is also concerned about the C$30 billion in government-guaranteed debt of Ontario Hydro, which is owned by the province.
